title: #306 The Next Generation of Business Intelligence with Colin Zima, CEO at Omni

rawLines.text:
welcome to dataf framed This is Richie Analytics 
tooling has diverged On the one hand you've got

a lot of sophisticated tools for data scientists 
and on the other hand spreadsheets still remain

ubiquitous for quick and dirty analyses BI 
tools fit somewhere in between and there are

a lot of great options However today's guest 
thinks that there are no great BI solutions

that work for both audiences That's why he 
set out to build his own Colin Zema was an

early executive at Looker where he was chief 
analytics officer and VP of product In 2022

he went his own way and founded Omni in order 
to build a next generation BI platform As CEO

he's now taking on PowerBI Tableau Looker and 
a host of other players with big tech backing

It's that kind of ambition that makes you want to 
know more Of course I'm always keen for tips on

how to create a better dashboard too Let's find 
out what the next generation of BI will involve

You have to understand how the business works Like 
you obviously need the foundational understanding

of sort of data movement and all of those sorts 
of things The the way I would explain it is build

the sales dashboard like you're responsible for 
sales Don't build it like someone asked you to

build a sales dashboard I think ultimately what 
a data product is is just a highly curated very

wellplanned data asset in comparison to more of

that you care about are how does the user interact

visual quality of that object but I really think 
about these things as mostly products not data

products in any special sense Hi Colin welcome 
to the show Thanks for having me Now I make you

justify your existence a bit So there are a lot of 
very mature BI tools at the moment Why do we need

another one it's a tough one because I think um 
it's interesting because BI is one of these spaces

where every company is also trying to build their

a little bit better I mean I I think the funny 
story for me is I actually started a previous

company I really hated it the first time I hated

difficult to sort of wake up and motivate yourself 
every day if you don't strongly believe in what

you are doing And almost the only reason that 
Omni exists is because I sort of experienced this

frustration as a data person over like the last 
20 years where I had touched a bunch of different

tools and sort of felt the good and the bad of 
them and I wanted them all to exist in one place

So the very simple story is I I started in finance 
grew up in Excel sort of learned everything data

from an Excel context Ended up later in BI uh got 
exposed to Looker data modeling like very heavy

SQL concepts And I was always frustrated that 
tools couldn't do both of those things at the

same time Like there's a time and a place to cut 
corners and go really fast and be a little messy

And there's also a time and a place to operate 
like a software engineer and have governance and

centralization we just kind of never felt like 
it was getting executed and after Looker went

through an acquisition and sort of started slowing 
down we said "Let's go let's go try to build it."

And that's kind of what AMI has been Okay that's 
very interesting There's this sort of divergence

of tools I'm certainly Yeah there's a ton of very 
technical tools around like if you're a hardcore

data scientist or hardcore sort of data modeler 
lots of great tools for that And then spreadsheets

are sort of ubiquitous as well for more casual 
analyses And yeah you're right that the two

things haven't really come together in some way

you want to do these sort of fast casual analyses 
and when do you want something that's a bit more

rigorous So I think I think that is actually sort 
of the core of the problem for a lot of this stuff

which is you don't always know I mean obviously 
there's foundational concepts that you want

modeled at sort of the baseline so that everyone 
can do better The example that I always cite is

Salesforce's API puts out deleted records Maybe 
someone needs those at some very obscure moment

but effectively no one needs the deleted records 
And so that is stuff that you want controlled in

the ETL cycle cleaned up for everyone For all 
intents like you never want an end user to see

those things There's other stuff where you're 
starting an analysis and you realize you're at

the corner of what you are doing and to make a 
structural change would take you two hours and

sort of sidetrack you and you just want to sort of 
cut a corner and do a thing and sort of share the

question uh or share the answer to the question 
that the person asked you or that you have really

quickly And I think the the the challenge is often 
finding the place where you want to be governed

and you want to create a sandbox is actually 
really difficult because the lines blur all

over the place Like even for stuff that I would 
consider sort of messier for analytics So product

analytics is sort of a canonical example Does it

many people did a thing not really Like you're 
looking for directional analysis Even there you

probably want to template things that you come 
back to all the time But if your if your data

collection is JSON you want to be able to like 
reach into a JSON blob grab out a field and go do

a thing And so I I think the really hard part is 
that when when the paradigm shift is a completely

different set of tools or infrastructure it gets 
really hard to actually have that subtlety You

you get locked into the structure of a looker 
and really hardcore data modeling analytics

or you kind of throw your hands up and you say 
"Give me like a CSV and I'll go make it happen."

in Excel and and like same with a data science 
use case I I think my strong view is all of these

things tend to blur together in different ways at 
different times and you don't always know and thus

you need tooling that can actually be flexible 
and adapt Even when you start in one area you

might end up in the other area So the like the 
example I always sort of thought was sometimes

I'm writing one-off SQL because I have a one-off 
question and then you realize that thing you did

was important and needs to be sort of extended or

it out of your ad hoc tool into your govern tool

very hard to sort of say like this data is good

everyone and everything but sort of blurry lines

think uh you're right that a lot of data projects

your approach then like how do you have tooling

more rigorous I mean I think the most important 
sort of takeaway that we had at Looker So for

people that weren't familiar with Looker or I mean 
probably many are uh there's a data model and that

data model creates little building blocks of SQL 
So everything that you do on top of a data set

when you're writing SQL you can think about the 
little bricks that you fit together to write a

query like everything in the select statement the 
relationships the wear clause These are all just

little snippets of SQL that have use in different

divided regions into North America and Europe 
it doesn't matter whether I'm grouping by it or

filtering by it Region is a concept I want to use 
in many places Those core concepts drive all of

the centralized BI tools There's a data model You

rigid structure and effectively put pivot tables 
on top of them The sort of insight that we had

sort of leaving Looker was that all of the things 
that users are doing in UIs in even spreadsheets

or writing raw SQL can actually be templated

we might not be perfect at it but we can break it

lines of SQL and break it into thoughtful building

different ways But essentially what our tool does

Excel things we understand the components that sit

and thus when you decide that you want to take it

structured we've pre-prepared those pieces for

and sort of work with them like a mature BI tool 
and that was sort of the concept is I think every

major tool runs into these problems over time

can write SQL like ultimately every tool is trying

the challenge is if you're not thinking about that

layers can become very challenging because your 
post-processing calculation layer that's like

Excel doesn't talk the same way as your data 
modeling layer But if you actually do the work

up front to sort of think about how these things

And that was sort of the really core insight that 
we had about building the tool that enables you to

write a calculation that is row one minus row two 
And we understand that that's like a lag function

in SQL and can kind of pull it back and do things 
with it if you want to use it in another context

That is essentially the the building block of 
AMI Okay So I do like the idea of automatically

doing the data modeling in the background Now I'm

here but I would say in general data modeling is

yeah having that uh automated does seem like uh

um or where Omni fits into a larger sort of data

Um so Red Shift Snowflake Data Bricks Mother Duck
